awd_titl_txt: The Biology, Coastal and Marine Science, Molecular and Cellular Biology, and Neuroscience Scholarship Program
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Sacred Heart University (SHU) in Fairfield, CT. Throughout its five years of funding, this project will fund 56 annual scholarships to provide four years of support for two cohorts of seven students.  Scholars will be pursuing bachelor's degrees in general biology, coastal and marine science, molecular and cellular biology, or neuroscience. The project is designed to ensure that students from lower socioeconomic backgrounds will have strong faculty and peer relationships that can support learning activities, thus improving student achievement and retention. 

This S-STEM Track 2 project will implement the following activities: a pre-fall orientation, biology-focused first-year seminar courses, faculty mentoring, peer-led team learning in four biology courses, learning communities that extend throughout all four years, research experiences, and a research and career "STEMinar" series. Cohort-based activities for the scholars, regardless of major, will expose the scholars to the diversity of perspectives found in the biological sciences. SHU will conduct a research study to investigate the effects of student-faculty and student-peer support on achievement, retention, and graduation. The objectives are to enroll 14 scholars, retain 12 of the original 14 (86%) until their sophomore year, retain 10 of the 14 (71%) through graduation in four years, and place 12 out of 14 in STEM-related careers or graduate school within one year of graduation.  Scholars who leave the program will be replaced.  The project aims to strengthen existing relationships with industry partners and graduate programs, and to foster new ones. The project management team will gain and disseminate new knowledge related to the impact of providing strong faculty mentoring across all four years of study, combined with enhanced peer relationships through the implementation of peer-led team learning in courses that are identified attrition points.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sacred Heart University's "Involvement in Coastal and Marine, Molecular, and Neuroscience" (In-CoMMoN) program provided scholarships and comprehensive support to academically talented, financially challenged students pursuing biology degrees. This NSF-funded initiative aimed to increase participation in STEM fields while developing effective strategies for supporting student success.

Over the program's duration, In-CoMMoN retained nine scholars (out of an overall goal of 14) through graduation, completing degrees in biology, neuroscience, and molecular/cellular biology.

The program implemented several high-impact practices that proved crucial for student success:

  • A pre-fall orientation program helping new students acclimate to college life
  • Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL) providing structured academic support
  • Faculty mentoring and advising
  • Research opportunities both on campus and through external partnerships
  • Professional development seminars ("STEMinars")
  • First-year seminar courses

While the COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupted program activities, particularly affecting the second cohorts' ability to build community and persist in their pursuit of STEM degrees, the program demonstrated remarkable resilience. Students continued to excel academically and pursue their STEM aspirations despite these challenges. All nine graduating scholars have either entered STEM careers or pursued advanced education, including positions at biotech firms, healthcare organizations, and prestigious research institutions.

The program's broader impacts extend beyond individual student success. Several key initiatives, particularly the peer instructional "Learning Lab" model of student support and enhanced faculty mentoring, have been institutionalized across Sacred Heart's biology department and are being considered for adoption by other departments. This sustainability ensures the program's positive effects will continue benefiting students beyond the grant period.

Student testimonials consistently highlighted three crucial program elements:

  1. Financial support that made college attendance possible
  2. Academic support services that built confidence and competence
  3. Community building that created a sense of belonging in STEM

One scholar captured the program's impact: "The moment that I got selected to be a part of this program made me feel seen and proud of my grades, my major and my future."

The In-CoMMoN program demonstrated that with appropriate financial and academic support, talented students from economically challenged backgrounds can thrive in STEM fields. Its success provides a model for other institutions seeking to expand opportunities in scientific education while building a more inclusive STEM workforce.

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2025
Modified by: Kirk A Bartholomew
